. Therefore, starting from a monoclinic layered perovskite LTO
structure, the gradual substitution of Ti by Zr would yield structures that are increasingly more resistant to elec-
tronic excitations, with the cubic pyrochlore LZO being the most resistant to electronic excitation. This overall
trend is in agreement with several experimental observations
, which found that the susceptibility to amor-
phization by electronic excitation increases with cation radius ratio r
. In the case of cubic LZO and mono-
ratio is 1.61 and 1.92 respectively, making the LZO pyrochlore phase more resistant to
electronic excitation. It is worth noting that the increase in electronic excitation resistance shown in Fig.Â
monotonic; a monoclinic compound with 50% Zr is predicted to have a similar transition temperature to a cubic
compound with 75% Zr. While only the monoclinic and cubic phases were considered to model the phase transi-
tion between LTO and LZO, the potential for other phases to be involved in the transition region could lead to
some uncertainty in the amorphization behavior in this regime. We also note that the trend in the resistance to
electronic excitation follows the variations of the band gap (
) of the materials, which increases with Zr fraction.
While in each case the highest occupied orbitals are those of O
shows that the band gap reduction in
, compared to cubic LZO, is essentially due to the presence of unoccupied Ti
lower energy than the unoccupied Zr
shows that the presence of 50% Zr in mono-
clinic Z-LTO crystal allows to reduce the number of lower energy Ti
unoccupied states. Altogether, the panel of projected density of states shown in Fig.Â
cates that the band gap of the monoclinic phase with 50% Zr (Fig.Â
) is slightly larger than the band gap of the
that the radiation response cannot be solely described in terms of cation radius ratio and
as defect formation energy, bond type (i.e. covalency and ionicity), electronic structure of
the compounds, and energy of order-disorder transition, also play an important role in the amorphization resist-
ance of ceramics to electronic excitation
In order to evaluate the electronic changes associated with electronic excitation and excitation induced struc-
shows the modifications of the projected density of states for the monoclinic LTO
crystal under 0.8% electronic excitation, without and with excitation induced structural deformations. While
shows the same characteristics than Fig.Â
but to a lesser degree, Fig.Â
-like molecules in the structure, as induced by electronic excitation, tend to reduce the number of O
unoccupied and partially filled states near the Fermi level. The structural distortions also play a role in lowering
states, which contributes to reduce the energy gap between unoccupied O
states of the material compared to the pristine monoclinic LTO.
A comparison of our results with similar theoretical calculations performed for titanate pyrochlores by
complements and deepens our understanding of the effect of structure and composition on elec-
tronic excitation induced amorphization in ceramics. Especially, Fig.Â
shows that the evolution of transition
temperature with excitation concentration for the monoclinic layered perovskite LTO has a similar slope
compared to the other titanate pyrochlores, while cubic LZO pyrochlore exhibits a steeper slope. This sug-
gests that a chemical change of the
-site cation affects more strongly the slope of the transition temperature
as a function of excitation concentration, compared to a chemical change of the
shows that cubic pyrochlores are more resistant to electronic excitation than the monoclinic perovskite LTO
structure, as evidenced by their higher transition temperatures. In the specific case of a comparison between
, experiments have shown that the perovskite structure amorphizes more rapidly
. This is in agreement with LTO having a lower crystalline-to-amorphous
An analysis of the structural modifications obtained for cubic LZO and monoclinic LTO allows us to
identify the main structural features conferring resistance to electronic excitation. FigureÂ
ple of structural modifications obtained at 600 K and 0.8% excitation concentration for cubic LZO, and at
300 K and 0.8% excitation concentration for monoclinic LTO crystals. FigureÂ
Effect of structure, composition and excitation concentration on the crystalline-to-amorphous
transition temperature from the monoclinic perovskite to cubic pyrochlore structure.
